profileText: A Senator from Nevada; born in Fredonia, Wilson County, Kans., August 7, 1890; attended the public schools; graduated from the University of Nevada at Reno in 1917; engaged as a civil and hydraulic engineer at Reno, Nev., in 1914; during the First World War enlisted as a private in the Field Artillery; promoted to sergeant, and became a lieutenant and regimental intelligence officer, serving in England and France 1917-1919; State engineer of Nevada 1927-1935; special consultant to the United States Senate Military Affairs subcommittee on strategic and critical minerals and materials and for examination of military establishments during the Second World War; elected as a Republican to the United States Senate in 1946; reelected in 1952 and served from January 3, 1947, to January 3, 1959; unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1958 and for election to the United States House of Representatives in 1960; consulting engineer in Washington, D.C., until his death there on May 19, 1961; interment in Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, Va.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Malone, George W. Mainline. New Canaan, CT: Long House, 1958.

researchRecord.name: 1928-1961. 3 feet. Letters from Malone to his wife, Ruth "Katy'' (Moslander) Malone, and financial records, relating chiefly to the development of Industrial West Foundation, a nonprofit corporation of which he was founder; correspondence, telegrams, and press releases, mainly from his second term in the U.S. Senate (1953-1959) and his tour of Europe (1947); letters received in Washington, and photographs.
Correspondence in Effie Mona Mack papers, 1917-1969; George Wingfield papers; and various other collections.
Correspondence in Delph E. Carpenter papers, 1922-1945. Finding aid.

1930. 1 item. Report (14 pages) to the Committee on Conservation and Administration of the Public Domain recommending that all unappropriated, unreserved land be turned over to the states in fee simple.

recordLocation.name: Majority of Malone's papers were destroyed.
